questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with severe back pain, fatigue, confusion, and lethargy. Imaging reveals multiple osteolytic lesions; lab tests show elevated calcium and anemia, and serum protein electrophoresis identifies a monoclonal spike. Given this presentation, which complication is most likely contributing to his neurologic symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Spinal cord compression from vertebral collapse

options.label: B
options.text: Hyperviscosity syndrome from increased serum proteins

options.label: D
options.text: Peripheral neuropathy due to plasma cell infiltration

questions.explanation:
Bone manifestation

Bone pain is the most common symptom, affecting ~70% of patients. Persistent pain often indicates a pathologic fracture.

  • Caused by tumour cell proliferation, osteoclast activation, and osteoblast suppression.
  • Osteoclast activation is driven by cytokines like IL-1, VEGF, RANK ligand, and TNF, leading to bone destruction and lytic lesions.
  • Osteoblast suppression is mediated by DKK-1, resulting in minimal new bone formation.

Hypercalcemia: Results from bone destruction, causing both acute and chronic complications. Vertebral collapse may lead to spinal cord compression.

Infections
  • 2nd most common clinical issue
  • Frequent pathogens include S. pneumoniae, S. aureus, and K. pneumoniae in the lungs, and E. coli in the urinary tract.
  • Immune dysfunction is caused by hypogammaglobulinemia, abnormal T-cell function (reduced TH1, increased TH17), and impaired complement activity.

Renal Manifestation

Common causes include hypercalcemia (most common), amyloid deposits, hyperuricemia, infections, NSAIDs, iodinated contrast, bisphosphonates, and myeloma cell infiltration.

  • Light Chain Damage: Excessive light chains in tubules cause damage, leading to adult Fanconi's syndrome (proximal renal tubular acidosis) with loss of glucose, amino acids, and impaired kidney function.
  • Proteinuria: Mainly light chain proteinuria, minimal albumin unless glomeruli are involved.
  • Decreased anion gap due to cationic M component causing chloride retention. Pseudohyponatremia may occur due to reduced serum water content from increased proteins (Increased proteins retain water, leading to falsely low sodium levels)
  • Patients are susceptible to renal failure, especially if dehydrated.
  • Anemia: Normocytic, normochromic anaemia occurs in ~80% of patients due to marrow replacement, reduced erythropoietin production, and therapy effects. Some may develop megaloblastic anaemia due to folate or B12 deficiency.
  • Clotting Abnormalities: Dysfunctional antibody-coated platelets and interactions between the M component and clotting factors can lead to clotting issues.

Hyperviscosity Syndrome: Caused by high paraprotein concentrations (especially IgM, IgG3, IgA), leading to increased serum viscosity. Symptoms include headache, visual disturbances, fatigue, and coma. (Option B)

Neurologic Symptoms: Causes include hypercalcemia (lethargy, confusion) (Option C), hyperviscosity (ataxia, coma), and bony damage (cord compression, radicular pain). Peripheral nerve infiltration by amyloid can cause neuropathy. (Option D)

Tumor Expansion: Although plasma cells spread widely, tumour expansion predominantly occurs within bone and bone marrow, with minimal involvement of lymph nodes, spleen, or gut-associated lymph tissue.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the gastroenterology clinic complaining of recurrent, burning abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss for the past few months. He says the pain is not relieved by taking antacids. Laboratory investigations show elevated serum gastrin levels, prompting further evaluation. Endoscopic examination reveals multiple peptic ulcers in the stomach and duodenum. 1) It is associated with MEN 2 syndrome. 2) 60% of the tumors have a malignant potential. 3) It is associated with H. pylori infection. 4) Diarrhea is the second most common clinical manifestation. 5) BAO: MAO ratio > 0.6 is suggestive of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Which of the following statements are true regarding this condition?
questions.explanation:
Abdominal pain

Due to peptic ulcer (M/C- >90%). ZES is suspected if:

  • Ulcers in unusual locations (2nd part of the duodenum and beyond).
  • Refractory to medical therapy.
  • Recurrence after acid-reducing surgery.
  • Presents with complications like bleeding and perforation.
  • It is not associated with H. pylori or NSAID intake. (Statement 3)

Diarrhea

Second most common (70%) clinical manifestation.

Causes are multifactorial and occur due to: (Statement 4)

  • Marked volume overload to the small bowel.
  • Inactivation of pancreatic enzymes by the acid.
  • Damage to the intestinal epithelium by the acid (can cause malabsorption and weight loss).
  • Diarrhea can also be secretory due to the direct stimulatory effect of gastrin on the enterocytes.

Association with MEN 1 syndrome
  • 25% of the cases can be associated with MEN 1.
  • ZES has a more indolent course in MEN 1, and the gastrinomas tend to be smaller, multiple, and located in the duodenal wall more often. (Statement 1)

Gastric pH

< 3

Serum gastrin

>1000 pg/ml

Secretin stimulation test (most sensitive and specific gastrin provocation test)

An increase in gastrin of ≥120 pg within 15 min of secretin injection

BAO (basal acid output)

>15 mEq/h (normal: <5 mEq/h)

BAO: MAO (maximal acid output) ratio

Increased (>0.6) (Statement 5)

Localization of the tumour
  • CT or MRI
  • Endoscopic ultrasound
  • PET-CT with 68Ga-DOTATATE (sensitivity & specificity is >90%)

Stages of Syphilis

Treatment

Primary syphilis

Chancre (painless genital ulcer)

Secondary syphilis

Spread in blood: Rash involving palms and soles, uveitis

Single IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU

Activation after one year and damages the organs (gummas)

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents with intense pain in his left leg along with the following lesion. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Venous ulcer

(Option B)

Arterial ulcer

(Option C)

Neuropathic ulcer

(Option A)

Pressure ulcer

(Option D)

Site

Gaiter’s area (area between malleolus and calf)

At distal ends of limbs, such as toes, feet and legs.

Over toe joints, under the heel, over malleoli, under the metatarsal head, etc

Seen over pressure points, most common are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, hee, malleolus, occiput, etc

Appearance

Vertically oval with a sloping edge and will not penetrate deep fascia.

Punched-out edges are seen in this type of ulcer.

Ulcers can be associated with gangrene and abscesses; osteomyelitis can be seen here.

Punched out ulcer with bone as a base.

Cause

Caused by ambulatory chronic venous hypertension due to varicose veins.

This occurs due to severe arterial insufficiency of digital and medium-sized arteries, leading to ischemia and tissue death in the region.

It is caused due to repeated trauma and ischemia due to microangiopathy in diabetic patients.

It is tissue necrosis and ulceration due to prolonged pressure on any part of the body.

Characteristics

It is initially painful, then chronically becomes painless.

It heals on rest and treatment but reforms again.

It is intensely painful, distal pulses are not palpable, associated with shiny skin, brittle nails and loss of hair over the region.

Also known as diabetic ulcer since it is seen in diabetic patients.

It is common in bedridden patients with head injuries, neurological deficits, and comatose and stroke-ridden patients.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with symptoms of a respiratory infection. A sputum sample is taken and cultured. The isolated organism shows pink, mucoid colonies on MacConkey agar. Biochemical tests are performed, and the organism is found to be urease-positive, indole-negative, and citrate-positive. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?

A researcher is studying various sensory receptors and their responses to different stimuli. During an experiment with pacinian corpuscle, the researcher notes that the intensity of the initial electrical response in the receptor is proportionate with the mechanical pressure applied. What is the initial graded electrical response observed in sensory receptors upon stimulus application?
questions.explanation:
Pacinian Corpuscle Mechanism

Mechanical Stimulation

  • Pressure deforms lamellae surrounding sensory nerve ending.

Ion Channels

  • Deformation opens mechanically-gated ion channels, mainly sodium (Na+).

Sodium Influx

  • Rapid influx of Na+ generates the receptor potential.

Graded Response

  • Larger deformation (stronger stimulus) leads to a larger receptor potential.

Action Potential

  • If the potential reaches ~10 mV, an action potential is generated at the first Node of Ranvier.

questions.text: A 65-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with a history of multiple fragility fractures. She has been previously treated for osteoporosis but continues to experience bone loss. Which medication would be most appropriate to stimulate bone formation in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Pharmacological Agent

Mechanism of Action

Bisphosphonates (Option A)

Interfere with osteoclast activity, leading to decreased bone resorption.

Calcitonin (Option B)

Inhibits osteoclast activity, reducing bone resorption.

Denosumab (Option C)

It inhibits the RANK ligand, essential for osteoclast formation and function.

Estrogen/Raloxifene

Inhibit osteoclast activity and slow bone loss.

Cinacalcet

Indirectly reduces bone resorption by lowering PTH levels. (by stimulating CaSR receptors)

 

Teriparatide

A recombinant form of PTH stimulates osteoblast activity.

Strontium Ranelate

Dual action: It promotes bone formation by stimulating osteoblasts and decreases bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclast activity.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about platelets are true?

options.label: A
options.text: Alpha granules contain clotting factors and platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)

options.label: B
options.text: Splenectomy causes a decrease in the platelet count

options.label: C
options.text: Interleukins IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, and IL-7 are involved in stimulating platelet production

options.label: D
options.text: Thrombopoietin is produced exclusively by megakaryocytes and regulates platelet production

questions.correct_answer: A. Alpha granules contain clotting factors and platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)
questions.explanation:
Platelets

General Description

Small, granulated, non-nucleated discs important for hemostasis

Size

1-4 µm in diameter

Concentration in Blood

150,000 - 450,000/µL

Half-life

~4 days

Origin

Formed from megakaryocytes in the bone marrow

Distribution

60-75% in circulation; the remainder mainly in the spleen

Splenectomy Effect

Causes an increase in platelet count (thrombocytosis) (Option B)

Thrombopoietin

Produced by liver and kidneys; regulates platelet production (Option D)

Membrane Receptors

For collagen, ADP, von Willebrand factor and fibrinogen

Cytoplasmic Components

Actin, myosin, glycogen, lysosomes and granules

Granules
  • Alpha granules: Soluble coagulation proteins (vWF, Factor V, II), adhesion molecule, growth factor (IGF, PDGF, TGF-β, platelet factor 4), Integrin, Cytokines (Option A)
  • Dense granules: ADP, ATP, Calcium, Serotonin

Response to Injury

Adhere to exposed collagen and von Willebrand factor; release granule contents upon activation

Deficiency Effect

Thrombocytopenic purpura (easy bruising, multiple subcutaneous hemorrhages)

Interleukins

IL-1, IL-3, IL-6, IL-11 stimulate platelet production (Option C)

Factors increasing platelet synthesis

Inflammation, thrombopoietin and IL-1, IL-3, IL-6, IL-11

questions.explanation:
Type of Therapy

Description

Indication

Combination Therapy

Pharmacotherapy + Psychotherapy

Combines medications (e.g., antidepressants) with psychotherapy for a higher response rate.

Moderate to severe depression

Single Therapy

Psychotherapy alone may be sufficient for mild cases.

Mild depression

Psychotherapy Type

Description

Focus

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) (Option A)

Evidence-based therapy focusing on correcting cognitive distortions and maladaptive behaviors.

Developing healthier thought patterns and coping strategies.

Interpersonal Therapy (IPT)

Addresses current interpersonal problems, including family dynamics and relationship issues.

Enhancing social support and resolving conflicts.

Family Therapy (Option D)

Involves family members to improve communication and resolve conflicts.

Family dynamics and relationships.

Psychoanalytically Oriented Therapy

Uncovers unconscious motivations and past experiences affecting behavior.

Insight into past influences on current behavior.

Behavior Therapy

Utilizes reinforcement techniques to modify problematic behaviors.

Behavior modification and improvement.

Treatment

Mechanism/Procedure

Indication

Considerations

Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT)

Induces controlled seizures under anesthesia and muscle relaxant. Used to rapidly alleviate severe depressive symptoms.

Severe depression, especially with suicidal risk or psychotic features.

Safe for pregnant patients.

Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS)

Uses short pulses of magnetic energy to stimulate brain nerve cells involved in mood regulation.

Patients unresponsive to at least one antidepressant.

Non-invasive, no anesthesia required.

Vagal Nerve Stimulation (VNS)

The electrodes are implanted to stimulate the left vagus nerve and regulate mood.

Chronic or treatment-resistant depression.

Considered after other treatments have failed.

Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS)

Implantation of leads in specific brain areas associated with mood regulation.

Chronic or intractable depression.

Considered after multiple treatment failures.

Phototherapy

Uses bright light (1500-10,000 Lux) from a specialized lightbox for 1 to 2 hours daily to regulate circadian rhythms.

Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD).

Effective for seasonal mood changes.

Sleep Deprivation

Provides significant but short-lived benefits in alleviating depressive symptoms through controlled sleep loss.

Temporary relief from depressive symptoms.

Effects reverse after normal sleep resumes.

A 65-year-old patient presents with a 2.5 cm ulcerative lesion on the right side of his lower lip confirmed as squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the primary lymphatic drainage and surgical management of this lesion?

options.label: A
options.text: Drains to submental nodes; level I neck dissection is sufficient.

options.label: B
options.text: Drains to ipsilateral submandibular nodes; levels I-III neck dissection is recommended.

options.label: C
options.text: High risk of contralateral metastasis; bilateral neck dissection is needed.

options.label: D
options.text: Drains to preauricular and parotid nodes; requires superficial parotidectomy.

questions.correct_answer: B. Drains to ipsilateral submandibular nodes; levels I-III neck dissection is recommended.
questions.explanation:
Common Causes
  • UV radiation exposure
  • Tobacco use
  • Chronic irritation (e.g., ill-fitting dentures)
  • Immunosuppression
  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection
  • Chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., actinic cheilitis)

Clinical Features
  • Non-healing progressive painless ulcer
  • Everted edge with indurations
  • Growth moves with the lip
  • Submental, submandibular and upper deep neck nodes may get enlarged.
  • Tender firm lymph nodes may be due to infection; hard initially non-tender nodes are due to carcinoma spread.
  • Fungation, bleeding, halitosis.

Diagnosis
  • Wedge biopsy
  • FNAC of lymph nodes
  • CT/MRI head and neck

Management

  1. Early Stage (T1-T2N0):
  • Wide local excision with 1 cm margins
  • Consider elective neck dissection for tumors >2 cm or >4 mm depth
  • Reconstruction: Primary closure, local flaps, or skin grafts
 
  1. Advanced Stage (T3-T4 or N+):
  • Wide local excision with ≥1 cm margins
  • Neck dissection (comprehensive or selective based on nodal status)
  • Complex reconstruction (local/regional flaps, free tissue transfer)
  • Adjuvant radiotherapy or chemoradiotherapy based on pathological findings
 
  1. Management of the Neck:
  • Elective neck dissection for high-risk tumors (>2 cm, >4 mm depth)
  • Therapeutic neck dissection for clinically positive nodes
  • Levels typically addressed: I-III for N0 neck, I-V for N+ neck

questions.explanation:
Bone Marrow

Biochemical Tests
  • Hypercellular bone marrow
  • Erythroid Hyperplasia
  • Sieve-like chromatin (Option: B).
  • Hypersegmented neutrophils
  • Reversal of myeloid: erythroid ratio 1:1 or less (Normal: 3:1) (Option A)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman visits the clinic after experiencing persistent sadness, increased anxiety, and sleep disturbances for the past month. She recently went through a traumatic event involving the loss of a loved one. She reports feeling overwhelmed and unable to cope with her emotions. What type of depression is she most likely experiencing?

options.text: Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features

questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:
  • ↳ Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Page 175

Feature

Endogenous Depression

(Option A)

Exogenous (Reactive) Depression

(Option B)

Definition

Primarily caused by biological factors.

Arises due to psychological or environmental factors.

Precipitating Events

Manifests without identifiable precipitating events.

Triggered by specific life events (e.g., loss, trauma).

Symptoms

Characterized by melancholic or psychotic features.

Exhibits multiple somatic complaints and emotional distress.

Mood Regulation

Linked to genetic or neurochemical factors affecting mood.

Relates to an individual's emotional response to their circumstances.

Treatment Response

Often requires pharmacological treatment (e.g., antidepressants).

May respond well to psychotherapy and counseling focused on coping strategies.

Duration

Symptoms can be persistent and chronic.

Symptoms may be more acute and linked to the duration of the triggering event.

questions.text: A 9 year old boy frequently argues with his parents and teachers, often refuses to follow rules, and deliberately annoys his classmates. He seems angry most of the time but has no history of physical aggression or breaking the law. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Disorder

Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD)

Conduct Disorder

Definition

The persistent pattern of negativistic, defiant, disobedient, and hostile behaviour toward authority figures.

A persistent pattern of behaviour involving aggression, violating others' rights, and disregarding social norms.

Diagnostic Criteria (DSM-5)
  • Duration: ≥6 months.
  • Symptoms (≥4):
  • Losing temper.
  • Easily annoyed/sensitive.
  • Angry/resentful.
  • Argues with authority figures.
  • Refuses requests/rules.
  • Deliberately annoys others.
  • Blames others for their own mistakes/behaviors.
  • Spiteful/vindictive (at least 2x in 6 months).
  • No severely aggressive or delinquent behaviours.
  • Duration: ≥12 months, with 1 symptom present in the last 6 months.
  • Symptoms (≥3):
  • Physical aggression or threats.
  • Destruction of property.
  • Deceitfulness or theft.
  • Harming animals.
  • Violation of rules (e.g., truancy, running away).

Types (DSM-5)
  • Angry/Irritable Mood: Frequent temper loss, persistent irritability.
  • Argumentative/Defiant Behavior: Argues, refuses to comply, blames others.
  • Vindictiveness: Spiteful/vindictive actions ≥2x in 6 months.
  • Childhood-onset: Symptoms before age 10.
  • Adolescent-Onset: Symptoms after age 10.
  • Unspecified-Onset: Age of onset unknown

Severity Specifiers
  • Mild: Symptoms in 1 setting.
  • Moderate: Symptoms in 2 settings.
  • Severe: Symptoms in ≥3 settings.
  • Mild: Few conduct problems, minor harm.
  • Moderate: Intermediate symptoms.
  • Severe: Many symptoms, significant harm caused.

Treatment
  • Family Interventions: Parent training in child management, reinforcing positive behaviour.
  • Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Parents are taught to discourage the child's oppositional behaviour by not paying much attention to it.
  • Parenting Techniques: Focus on reducing harsh punishment, and increasing positive interactions.
  • Psychosocial Interventions: Early intervention, CBT, school-based programs.
  • Pharmacologic Interventions: Antipsychotics (risperidone, quetiapine), SSRIs for impulsivity/irritability, sodium valproate.

questions.text: Match the following male reproductive organs with their homologous female reproductive organs. 1. Testes A. Bartholin's glands 2. Penis B. Ovaries 3. Scrotum C. Clitoris 4. Bulbourethral glands D. Labia majora
questions.explanation:
Homologous Structures

Testes - Ovaries
  • Derived from the undifferentiated gonadal ridge in the embryo.
  • Function as the primary reproductive organs, producing gametes and hormones.

Penis - Clitoris
  • Develops from the genital tubercle.
  • Sensitive erectile tissues involved in sexual arousal.

Scrotum - Labia majora
  • Develops from the labioscrotal swellings from mesoderm layer.
  • Serve as protective structures for the reproductive organs.

Penile urethra - Labia minora

Develops from the urethral folds.

Bulbourethral glands - Bartholin's glands
  • Develops from the urogenital sinus, which is part of the endodermal tissue.
  • Both glands secrete mucus to lubricate.

questions.text: A patient presents with features suggestive of Boerhaave syndrome. What is the characteristic triad seen in this condition?

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient undergoing hemodialysis suddenly develops symptoms of dizziness, significant leg cramps, and chest pain during the treatment session. Which of the following is the most common acute complication occurring in patients undergoing dialysis?
questions.explanation:
Intermittent Hemodialysis

Continuous Hemodialysis
  • Commonly used for acute kidney injury (AKI).
  • Blood is on one side of the dialysis machine, and dialysate is on the other side.
  • Transfer of substances occurs by diffusion and ultrafiltration.
  • Common complication: Hypotension.

 
  • Used in hemodynamically unstable patients.
  • Types:
    • Convective Clearance: Water and dissolved solutes pass through a semipermeable membrane; physiologic crystalloid solution is added to circulation.
    • Diffusive Clearance: Dialysis with a lower flow rate.
    • Hybrid Therapy: Combines both convective and diffusive clearance.

Complications associated with Hemodialysis

During treatment

Between treatment
  • Hypotension: The most common acute complication during hemodialysis, especially in patients with diabetes mellitus.
  • Muscle cramps.
  • Anaphylactoid reactions: These reactions, particularly to the dialyser, are most common during its first use and are often associated with bio incompatible cellulosic-containing membranes.
  • Cardiac arrhythmias: D/t potassium & acid-base shifts.
  • Hemorrhage: D/t anticoagulation & venous needle disconnection.
  • Air embolism: D/t faulty lines & equipment malfunction.
  • Pulmonary oedema (D/t fluid overload).
  • Systemic sepsis: Usually involves vascular access devices (catheter or fistula).
  • Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome typically occurs during or after a patient's first dialysis session. It presents with confusion, restlessness, headache, and muscle twitching. It is caused by a urea gradient between the CSF and blood that raises intracranial pressure.
  • Amyloidosis (D/t beta 2 microglobulin)
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome (due to amyloid deposition in the flexor retinaculum).
  • Peripheral neuropathy

questions.text: A 45-year-old man, two months post-kidney transplant, presents with sudden oliguria, fever, and graft site swelling. Biopsy shows glomerular and peritubular capillary inflammation with complement deposition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Acute humoral rejection

Acute cellular rejection
  • Acute humoral rejection mediated by newly synthesized antibodies.
  • It causes endothelial damage and complement activation.
  • Type II or IV hypersensitivity.
  • No response to increasing doses of immunosuppressive drugs.
  • Treatment: B cell depleting agents.
  • Microscopic appearance:
    • Fibrinoid necrosis in vessels.
    • Deposition of C4d in peritubular capillaries. (Complement breakdown product).
  • C4d is the marker for acute humoral rejection.
  • Mediated by CD4+ or CD8+ T cells.
  • Type IV hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Responsive to increasing doses of immunosuppressive drugs.
  • Microscopic appearance:
    • Tubulointerstitial pattern:
    • Tubulitis :
    • Destruction of tubules + inflammatory cells in tubules.
    • mononuclear inflammatory infiltrate.
    • vascular pattern:
    • Endothelitis

questions.text: A 45 y/o male patient presents with abdominal pain and distension. A CT scan reveals multiple appendices epiploicae, particularly prominent in the sigmoid colon. Which of the following statements regarding the anatomy of the large intestine is false?

options.text: Appendices epiploicae are more common in the distal colon.

questions.correct_answer: A. The caecum is typically 8-10 cm long and is a common site for appendices epiploicae.
questions.explanation:
Component

Description

Caecum (Option A)

Blind pouch at the beginning of the large intestine and is approximately 6 cm long

Vermiform Appendix

Narrow tube, 6-10 cm long, attached to the caecum

Ascending Colon

Travels upward from the caecum (20-25cm long)

Right Colic Flexure

Bend between ascending and transverse colon

Transverse Colon

Crosses the abdomen horizontally

Left Colic Flexure

Bend between transverse and descending colon

Descending Colon

Travels downward from the left colic flexure (10-15 cm long)

Sigmoid Colon

S-shaped segment leading to the rectum (Option B ruled out)

Rectum

Final straight portion, ~15 cm above the anal canal

Feature

Details

Description

Small, fat-filled pouches of peritoneum on the colon's surface.

Location

Few or absent on caecum and ascending colon (Option A).

More common on the distal colon (Option D ruled out).

Numerous on the sigmoid colon; can enlarge with obesity.

Absent on rectum.

Type of Taeniae Coli

Position

Located on the antimesenteric aspect, opposite the mesentery.

Omental Taenia

Positioned posterolaterally.

Mesocolic Taenia

questions.text: A 30-year-old female slipped while demonstrating an exercise in a fitness class, landing on her outstretched right arm. She arrives at the emergency department with severe pain in her right wrist and forearm. Upon examination, her wrist appears unstable. Based on the X-ray findings, which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?

options.label: D
options.text: Posterior interosseous nerve is commonly involved

questions.explanation:
Galeazzi fracture

Aetiology

  • It is more common in adults.
  • Three times more common than Monteggia fracture (Option C)

Mechanism

  • Fall on an outstretched hand (marked pronation of the forearm).
  • Direct blow on the dorsolateral side of the forearm

Clinical features

  • Prominence and tenderness at the distal end of the ulna (main feature).
  • Piano key sign: It is a deformity where the ulnar styloid moves up and down when pressure is applied, resembling a piano key. This movement indicates subluxation or dislocation of the joint.

X-ray

Reveals a fracture of the distal third of the radius and a dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint.

Treatment

Surgery is necessary (fracture of necessity) (Option A): ORIF with long plate and screw (treatment of choice).

 

Complications

  • Nerve injury
    • Ulnar nerve injury.
    • Anterior Interosseous nerve injury (Option D)
  • Entrapment of Extensor carpi ulnaris tendon (rare).

questions.text: A 40-year-old male was shot during a robbery while walking home at night. The weapon used was identified as a firearm, and forensic investigators recovered a bullet from the scene, as shown in the image below. Identify it.
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Images

Dum-dum bullet

(Option D)

A jacketed bullet that leaves an area near the nose uncovered to expose the core.

Hollow point bullet

(Option A)

The modern Dum Dum bullet features a pit at the nose. Upon impact, pressure in the pit causes the lead ring to expand into a mushroom shape, resulting in increased soft tissue damage and a higher incapacitation index.

Soft point bullet

A jacketed bullet with an open tip that exposes some lead inside expands upon impact but more slowly than a hollow-point bullet.

Tandem bullet (Piggyback bullet)

Bullets eject one after another when the first bullet fails to exit the barrel and is pushed out by a subsequently fired bullet (faulty ammunition or a firearm that hasn't been used for years).

Duplex bullet

It contains two projectiles by design (used in military rifles) and enters a target at different points.

Frangible bullet

Designed to fragment or disintegrate upon impact, made of copper, powdered tungsten, lead, or iron. They do not ricochet.

Souvenir or sleeping

Bullet (Option B)

A bullet remains in the body for a long time without fresh bleeding, surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule. It can result in lead poisoning.

  

Armour-piercing bullet

A jacketed bullet (penetrates armour) with an inner core of hard, high-density metal like tungsten, tungsten carbide, depleted uranium, or steel, featuring a truncated cone.

Incendiary bullet

(Option C)

A type of military bullet designed to ignite a fire in the target.

Tracer bullet

It leaves a visible mark or "trace" during flight, allowing the shooter to see where the shot impacts.

Nontoxic shot or Green bullet

It replaces the copper-jacketed lead core with a copper-jacketed tungsten, steel, bismuth, tin, or nylon core. It does not release toxic lead (lead-free) into the environment (green bullet).

Exploding bullet

A bullet designed to detonate or break apart uses an explosive or deflagrant, causing extensive damage to the victim. These bullets pose a risk to medical personnel, as they may explode during procedures if they fail to detonate in the body.

Boat tail bullet

The cartridge's rear end is tapered rather than squared off to stabilise the projectile in flight.

Poisoned bullets

Contains curare, ricin or aflatoxin.

  

Wadcutter

Specifically designed for shooting paper targets at close range and high velocities.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with a history of bloody diarrhea followed by decreased urine output, lethargy, and paleness. Laboratory tests reveal hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated creatinine levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Types and Causes
  • STEC-HUS: Caused by E. coli O157 (Shiga toxin)
  • Atypical HUS: Caused by genetic mutations, immune issues, pregnancy, cancers, medications

Pathophysiology and Pathology
  • Shiga toxin damages blood vessels in kidneys and brain

Clinical Features
  • Typical HUS: Bloody diarrhea, decreased urine output, paleness, lethargy, seizures
  • Atypical HUS: No bloody diarrhea, High blood pressure, mild breathing difficulties (Option C).

Diagnosis and Laboratory Investigations

Triad:

  • Hemolytic anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Acute kidney injury
 

Blood tests: Anemia, low platelet count, elevated creatinine

Stool cultures for E. coli O157 in STEC-HUS

Complications
  • Acute: Seizures, stroke, heart failure, death
  • Chronic: Chronic kidney disease (CKD)

Differential Diagnosis
  • ITP: Affects platelets only, lacks hemolytic anemia and kidney injury (Option A).
  • DIC: Widespread clotting and bleeding, different clinical features (DIC) (Option B)

Treatment
  • Supportive care
  • Plasma exchange for aHUS
  • Antibiotics not recommended for STEC-HUS

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with right lower quadrant pain for the past 24 hours. On examination, the surgeon demonstrates cutaneous hyperesthesia in an area bounded by a line joining the anterior superior iliac spine, the umbilicus, and the pubic symphysis. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this clinical sign?

options.label: A
options.text: This sign is known as Sherren's triangle and indicates retro-cecal appendicitis

options.label: B
options.text: The hyperesthesia is due to irritation of the T10-L1 nerve roots by the inflamed appendix

options.label: C
options.text: This sign is highly specific for appendicitis and rules out other causes of right lower quadrant pain

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of this sign contraindicates the use of laparoscopy for appendectomy

questions.correct_answer: B. The hyperesthesia is due to irritation of the T10-L1 nerve roots by the inflamed appendix
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Option D)

Symptoms

Pain

Initial: Vague, dull pain around the umbilicus.

Progression: Pain localizes to the right lower quadrant (RLQ) due to parietal peritoneum involvement.

Nausea and Vomiting

Due to abdominal inflammation.

Anorexia

Loss of appetite.

Signs

Tenderness

Tenderness at McBurney's point (one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus on the right side).

Rebound Tenderness

Increased pain upon sudden release of pressure on the abdomen, indicating peritoneal irritation.

Rovsing's Sign

Positive when palpation of the left lower quadrant causes pain in the right lower quadrant, suggesting peritoneal irritation.

Psoas Sign

Pain on passive extension of the right hip, indicating irritation of the iliopsoas muscle group.

Obturator Sign

Pain elicited by internal rotation of the right thigh while supine, suggesting irritation of the obturator internus muscle.

Dunphy's Sign

Increased pain in the RLQ with coughing, indicating peritoneal irritation.

Aaron's Sign

Referred pain in the epigastrium upon pressure over McBurney's point.

Ten Horn Sign

Increased pain during gentle traction or pulling of the right testicle in male patients, suggesting an inflamed appendix close to the right spermatic cord.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle accident. On examination, he has a high-riding prostate on rectal exam, and blood is noted at the urethral meatus. He complains of difficulty in urination, and imaging reveals a pelvic fracture. Retrograde urethrography confirms a complete disruption of the posterior urethra. After initial stabilization, Which of the following is the most definitive method of management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate Surgical Repair of the Urethra

questions.explanation:
Anterior Urethral Injuries

Posterior Urethral Injuries

Management
  • Minor Injuries: Managed conservatively with catheterization or suprapubic catheter if severe bruising
  • Severe Injuries: Surgical intervention like primary repair, urethroplasty, or end-to-end anastomosis
  • Antibiotics: To prevent infection
  • Initial Management: Suprapubic catheterization for urinary diversion
  • Delayed Urethroplasty (Definitive management): 3-6 months post-injury after inflammation and fibrosis have subsided
  • Primary Realignment: Occasionally attempted if conditions permit
  • Endoscopic Realignment: For selected cases, though often reserved for acute management

Complications
  • Urethral stricture (risk of recurrence)
  • Erectile dysfunction (especially if injury near the penile base)
  • Urinary incontinence (less common)
  • Infection (urethritis or abscess formation)
  • Urethral stricture (most common long-term complication)
  • Urinary incontinence (due to sphincter damage)
  • Erectile dysfunction (common, due to injury near neurovascular structures)
  • Bladder neck contracture
  • Chronic pelvic syndrome

Short-term Storage

(24 to 96 hours)

Intermediate-term Storage

(up to 2 weeks)

Long-term Preservation

(months to years):
  • Moist Chamber Method: Preserve the whole globe at 4°C in a refrigerator for up to 48 hours.
  • McCarey Kaufman (M-K) Medium:
  • Pink-colored medium containing TC-199, Dextran-40, HEPES buffer, and gentamicin.
  • Optisol GS:

  • Organ Culture Method: Preserves cornea at 30°C to 37°C for up to 35 days.
  • Cryopreservation: Preserves corneal button at -70°C for up to 1 year.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with jaw pain, swelling, difficulty opening his mouth, and trouble chewing after being struck in the face during a fight. What is the most common site for mandibular fractures?

Which two of the following statements about serous, mucinous, and mixed glands are correct? Serous glands produce a proteinaceous, enzyme-rich watery fluid, while mucinous glands secrete mucopolysaccharides that form a thick, viscous mucus. Cells of serous acini are triangular with centrally placed rounded nuclei, whereas cells of mucous acini are tall with flat nuclei at their bases. The pancreas is an example of a mixed gland, containing both serous and mucous secreting acini. The lumen of mucous acini is typically smaller than that of serous acini.
questions.explanation:
Serous gland

Mucous gland

Mixed gland
  • The secretions of serous glands are proteinaceous in nature. Cells secrete an enzyme-rich watery fluid.
  • Cells of serous acini are triangular with a rounded nucleus. Their nuclei are centrally placed.
  • E.g. pancreas.
  • In mucous glands, the secretion contains mucopolysaccharides. Cells secrete mucus which is a thick, viscous, and jelly-like protective lubricant known as mucin.
  • Cells of mucous acini are tall with flat nuclei at their bases.
  • The lumen of these acini is larger than the serous acini
  • E. g. goblet cells, and minor salivary glands of the tongue and palate.
  • The gland contains acini that secrete both mucus and serous secretions
  • E.g. submandibular and sublingual glands.

questions.text: A 67-year-old female with a history of osteoarthritis, significantly affecting her quality of life, is scheduled for knee replacement surgery. After exploring her options, she decides to opt for epidural anaesthesia. All of the following are the disadvantages of epidural anaesthesia, except?

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with polyuria, growth failure, fair skin, blond hair, and photophobia. Slit-lamp examination reveals cystine crystals in the cornea. Which genetic mutation is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Cystinosis

Etiology

Mutations in the CTNS gene (Option C) (encoding the protein cystinosin, a cystine transporter) → Defect in cystinosin → Accumulation of cystine crystals in major organs (kidney, liver, eyes, brain)

Clinical Features
  • Severe tubular dysfunction, Fanconi syndrome, polyuria, polydipsia, growth failure, rickets, progressive tubulointerstitial fibrosis
  • Fever due to dehydration or diminished sweat production.
  • Fair skin, and blond hair due to diminished pigmentation.
  • Ocular issues: photophobia, retinopathy, impaired visual acuity.
  • Other features: hypothyroidism, hepatosplenomegaly, delayed sexual maturation.

Diagnosis
  • Detection of cystine crystals in the cornea.
  • Confirmed by measuring increased cystine content in leukocytes.

Treatment
  • Therapy with cysteamine (converts cystine to cysteine)
  • Cysteamine eye drops for ocular involvement.

(Option A)

questions.text: A 26 y/o woman presents with cramping and heavy vaginal bleeding at 10 weeks gestation. She had a previous cesarean delivery two years ago. Ultrasound confirms a diagnosis of incomplete abortion with retained products of conception. What is the most appropriate surgical management among the options provided?
questions.explanation:
Trimester

Procedure

Description

Image

1st

Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)
  • MVA is an outpatient surgical abortion procedure used up to 12 weeks of gestation.
  • The procedure involves dilating the cervix and inserting a cannula attached to a manual vacuum aspirator or a 60-mL syringe.
  • The cannula is used to remove retained tissue from the uterus.
  • The approximate pressure is around -610 mmHg.

 

Electric Vacuum Aspiration (EVA)
  • EVA is similar to MVA.
  • Instead of a manual syringe, it uses an electric pump to generate suction to remove retained products of conception.

 

 

Dilation and Curettage (D&C)

(Option B)
  • D&C is performed up to 12 weeks of gestation by dilating the cervix and using instruments like curettes and suction cannula.
  • MVA and EVA are preferred over sharp D&C for being safer and more efficient.

 

2nd

Dilation and Evacuation (D&E) (Option C)
  • D&E is a 2nd-trimester abortion method involving cervical dilation using osmotic dilators. Ovum forceps are then used to remove the pregnancy tissue.
  • Draining amniotic fluid before removing the fetus is crucial to minimize the risk of amniotic fluid embolism during the procedure.

 

 

Hysterotomy (Option D)
  • A hysterotomy is a surgical procedure where the uterus is incised to remove the fetus.
  • Reserved for 2nd-trimester abortions where other methods are not feasible or have failed.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male patient with a history of adrenal carcinoma and hypercortisolemia is scheduled for a surgical procedure. The anesthesiology team is evaluating induction agents that suppress adrenal function. Which of the following agents can be used in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Etomidate

Mechanisms of Action
  • Depresses the reticular activating system.
  • Mimics GABA's inhibitory effects by binding to GABA A receptors, particularly the R(+) isomer.

Structure-Activity Relationships
  • Contains a carboxylated imidazole
  • The imidazole ring provides water solubility in acidic solutions and lipid solubility at physiological pH.

Pharmacokinetics

Absorption: Only available for IV use, primarily for induction of anesthesia.

Distribution: Rapid onset due to high lipid solubility; redistribution lowers plasma concentration post-awakening.

Biotransformation: Rapidly hydrolyzed by hepatic microsomal enzymes to an inactive metabolite.

Excretion: Hydrolysis products are excreted in urine.

CNS Effects
  • Induces hypnosis via GABA A receptor modulation (0.3 mg/kg).
  • Reduces cerebral blood flow and cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen without affecting MAP.
  • Decreases intracranial pressure (ICP) by 50% in patients with increased ICP.

Respiratory Effects
  • Minimal impact on ventilation; does not release histamine.
  • May cause brief hyperventilation and mild apnea, with slight PaCO2 increase.

Cardiovascular Effects
  • Minimal impact on sympathetic tone and myocardial function.
  • It may cause mild arterial blood pressure decline without significant changes in cardiac output or contractility.

Endocrine Effects
  • Inhibits 11β-hydroxylase, reducing cortisol and mineralocorticoid production, leading to adrenal suppression. 

Clinical Uses
  • Induction dose: 0.2 to 0.6 mg/kg IV.
  • Suitable for patients with cardiovascular issues and
  • Increased ICP
  • Effective in treating endogenous hypercortisolemia.

Side Effects
  • Associated with postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV),
  • Pain on injection,
  • Myoclonic movements, and
  • Hiccups.

Pre-medication with lidocaine can reduce pain; myoclonus can be lowered with midazolam or magnesium.

Novel Derivatives
  • Methoxycarbonyl etomidate (MOC): Rapidly metabolized, minimal adrenal suppression, similar hypnotic potency.
  • Carboetomidate: Reduces adrenal suppression potency, maintains hypnotic effects, minimal hemodynamic changes.
  • Methoxycarbonyl-carboetomidate: Combines benefits of etomidate without adrenal suppression, longer action duration.
  • CPMM and DMMM: Newer derivatives showing higher potency and rapid recovery post-infusion, promising in animal studies.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a diagnosis of schizophrenia has been on antipsychotic medication for over a decade. Her family has noticed that she has been experiencing involuntary movements for the past few months, including repetitive facial grimacing, lip-smacking, and jerky motions of her arms and legs. What is the drug of choice for treatment of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Tardive dyskinesia

Description

A delayed effect (abnormal involuntary movements) of antipsychotics typically occurs until after 6 months of treatment.

Cause

Supersensitization of dopamine (D) receptors due to prolonged exposure to antipsychotic medications.

Manifestations

Abnormal, involuntary movements such as:

  • Lip smacking
  • Chewing
  • Darting, twisting, and protrusion of the tongue (catching fly)
  • Choreiform hand movements (playing piano)
  • Facial grimacing
  • Finger movements and hand clenching
 

In Severe cases:

  • Torticollis (twisting of neck muscles to one side)
  • Retrocollis (neck extension)
  • Trunk twisting
  • Pelvic thrusting

Management

Prevention: Using antipsychotic medications only when indicated and in the lowest effective doses.

 

Regular monitoring: Patients taking antipsychotics should be regularly assessed for any signs of abnormal movements.

 

Treatment:

  • Reducing antipsychotic drugs (or stop if possible)
  • Switching the medication to clozapine (least EPS-causing) or atypical antipsychotics
  • VMAT (Vesicular Monoamine Transporter type 2) receptor inhibitor:
    • Valbenazine (drug of choice) (Option D)
    • Tetrabenazine- Lesser efficacy, more sedation than Valbenazine (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 65 y/o patient with a history of complete heart block presents for follow-up. The patient's ECG shows an idioventricular rhythm with a ventricular rate of 30 beats per minute. What is the most likely location of the pacemaker driving the patient's idioventricular rhythm?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer:D) Purkinje Fibres

Aspect

SA Node

AV Node

Intrinsic Rhythmicity

60-80 beats per minute(can go upto 100) (natural pacemaker of the heart) (Option A)

40-60 beats per minute (Option B)

Location

The upper wall of the right atrium

The lower wall of the right atrium

Function

The primary pacemaker; initiates the heart's rhythmic contractions

Delays impulses from atria; ensures coordinated contractions

Action Potential

Calcium-driven, slower conduction

Prepotentials

Present - Slow, gradual depolarizations observed

Parasympathetic Modulation

Acetylcholine decreases the firing rate

Ach decreases the firing rate by hyperpolarizing nodal cells, increasing potassium conductance, slowing the "funny" current (Ih), and reducing cAMP levels.

Sympathetic Modulation

Norepinephrine increases the firing rate

Norepinephrine: Increases firing rate by binding to β1 receptors, raising cAMP levels, and facilitating L-type calcium channel opening, accelerating depolarization.

Role in Heart Block

Fastest intrinsic rate, so normally unaffected

It can be a site of conduction disruption leading to heart block

questions.explanation:
Step

Details

Request for Examination
  • Any police officer can request it within 24 hours.

Consent
  • Must obtain consent from the woman
  • Examination supervised by a female RMP.

Initial Examination
  • Ask the victim to remove clothing.
  • Examine and collect evidence from clothes.
  • Look for foreign objects (hairs, seminal stains) (Option A)
  • Search for physical injuries.

Detection of Micro Injuries
  • Apply toluidine-blue contrast to the anogenital area.

Swabs Collection
  • 4 swabs:
    • Smear: Prepare a smear for microscopic examination.
    • Sperm: Use saline for motility testing.
    • DNA Profiling (Option D)
    • Chemical Tests: Acid phosphatase, creatinine phosphokinase, lactate dehydrogenase.

Examination Position
  • Examine in lithotomy position under good lighting.

Hymen Examination
  • Use Glaister-Keene rods or hymenoscope
  • Look for tears (usually posterior at 5-7 o'clock position).

Vaginal Examination
  • Use a speculum for vaginal examination.

Cervical Examination
  • Use a colposcope for cervical examination.

Post-Examination Care
  • Treat STDs, injuries, or potential pregnancy.
  • Provide psychological support.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with dark, hard nodules along his scalp hair, which he mistakenly believes to be lice nits. Upon microscopic examination, branched hyphae and arthrospores are observed. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Etiology

Caused by Piedraia hortae (dematiaceous fungus) (Option B).

Characteristics

Affects scalp hair; it is common in individuals with long hair and poor hygiene.

Clinical Features

Hard, black nodules that may resemble lice nits; complex structure of filamentous hyphae and spores; examined using KOH shows branched hyphae and arthrospores.

Diagnosis

Direct microscopic examination:

Branched hyphae and arthrospores

Culture:

Sabouraud dextrose agar shows dark colonies.

Treatment

Antifungal shampoos or systemic antifungals; treatment efficacy may be compromised by nodules' compact nature.

Aspect

Details

Etiology

Caused by Trichosporon species, commonly Trichosporon beigelli, Trichosporon inkin (Option A ruled out).

Characteristics

Affects facial, axillary, and pubic hair; typically asymptomatic.

Clinical Features

Whitish, loosely adherent nodules consisting of arthroconidia and blastoconidia.

Diagnosis

KOH examination and culture reveal yeast-like colonies.

Treatment

Topical antifungals such as ketoconazole shampoo.

Initiative

Aims

Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA)

(Option 1)

 

To offer free, comprehensive, and high-quality antenatal care to all pregnant women on the 9th of each month.

Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK)

Entitles all pregnant women giving birth in public health institutions to receive completely free services, including cesarean sections, and also covers free transportation.

Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) (Option 2)

To reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional deliveries among poor pregnant women through financial incentives.

Free, respectful healthcare with zero service denials, aiming to prevent maternal and newborn deaths. Beneficiaries include all pregnant women, up to 6 months post-delivery, and sick infants.

Dakshata Training

(Option 3)

A training program designed to enhance the skills and competencies of healthcare providers in intrapartum and immediate postpartum care.

  • Gross motor - Creeps well, walks but falls, stands without support

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a history of asthma is undergoing elective surgery. He is induced with isoflurane and given succinylcholine for muscle relaxation. Within minutes, the surgical team observes that he has developed severe muscle rigidity, a rapid heart rate, and a notable increase in body temperature. Which drug/s is/are most likely responsible for the onset of these symptoms in this patient?

A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with signs of infection. The physician discusses the components of his immune system that are involved in the initial defence against pathogens. Which of the following is NOT a component of innate immunity, as explained by the physician?

A 50-year-old woman presents with clear, watery nasal discharge that increases when she bends forward. She denies any history of allergies and reports having undergone nasal surgery a few weeks ago. Which biochemical test is the most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Glucose estimation test

Beta-2 Transferrin test

Beta trace protein test
  • Rapid but unreliable test using glucose oxidase paper.
  • Not specific for the site or side of the leak.
  • A protein unique to CSF, not found in nasal discharge.
  • Its presence is a specific and sensitive test for CSF rhinorrhea.
  • Requires only a few drops of CSF for testing.
  • Found in CSF, perilymph, and aqueous humor.
  • The best test for confirming CSF in nasal fluid, but doesn’t localize the leak.
  • Another protein-specific test to detect CSF.
  • Secreted by the meninges and choroid plexus.
  • Also known as prostaglandin D synthase.
  • High sensitivity and specificity.
  • Present in other tissues (testes, heart) and altered in conditions like renal failure and CNS diseases.
  • But, facilities to test these are not easily available. (Option D)

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presents with sudden onset fever and a rapidly enlarging tender lymph node in the left axilla. Considering the clinical history of plague, which of the following is not true regarding the vector responsible for transmission of this infection?

options.label: B
options.text: Pathogen undergoes development within the vector.

questions.explanation:
Mechanical vector

Biological vector

  • Infectious agent is mechanically transported on the feet or proboscis of the agent. (Option A)
  • It can also get passively excreted unchanged from the agent GIT. (Option D)

Infectious agents are taken up by the vector, where they can undergo a necessary development cycle. (Option B)

An agent does not undergo multiplication or development within the vector.

E.g., the spread of bacillary dysentery by houseflies.

Agent undergoes

  • Multiplication (propagative) - plague bacilli in fleas.
  • Development (cyclo-developmental) - microfilariae in culex mosquito.
  • Both (cyclo-propagative) - malaria parasites in Anopheles.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with a history of schizophrenia has been on antipsychotic treatment for three years. After being prescribed a new medication, she developed unusual muscle contractions in her neck and jaw within a week, resulting in difficulty controlling her head movements, which often twist to one side. Which pathway is primarily responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Pathway

Extent

Manifestations

Nigrostriatal pathway

(Option C)

A decrease in dopamine leads to abnormal movement symptoms like tremors, rigidity, dystonias, etc.

Mesolimbic pathway

(Option A)

An increase in dopamine levels leads to positive symptoms such as:

  • Delusion
  • Hallucination

Mesocortical pathway

(Option B)

A decrease in dopamine levels leads to negative symptoms such as:

  • Anhedonia (loss of interest)
  • Avolition (loss of will)
  • Affective blunting (inability to express emotions).
  • Asociality (decrease in drive to socialise).
  • Alogia (decrease in verbal communication).
  • Attention deficits
  • Apathy (lack of concern).

Tuberoinfundibular pathway

(Option D)

A decrease in dopamine levels leads to hyperprolactinemia, which manifests as:

  • Decreased libido (sex drive)
  • Decreased sexual dysfunction
  • Galactorrhea and amenorrhea (females)

Pathways

Control

Nigrostriatal pathway

Abnormal movements (dystonia)

Mesolimbic pathway

Positive symptoms

Mesocortical pathway

Negative symptoms

Tuberoinfundibular pathway

Hyperprolactinemia

questions.text: In a 65 y/o male with COPD showing signs of a bacterial respiratory infection, the sputum sample undergoes culture and sensitivity testing using the Epsilometer (E-test). Following incubation, an elliptical zone of inhibition is observed around the antibiotic strip. What is the primary advantage of using the E-test in this clinical context?

options.label: A
options.text: It identifies the specific bacterium causing the infection.

options.label: B
options.text: It determines the bacterium's resistance to all known antibiotics.

options.label: C
options.text: It provides a visual and precise measurement of the minimum inhibitory concentration of the antibiotic.

options.label: D
options.text: It allows for the immediate administration of antibiotics without further testing.

questions.correct_answer: C. It provides a visual and precise measurement of the minimum inhibitory concentration of the antibiotic.
questions.explanation:
Step

Description

Setup

An absorbent strip with a gradient of antibiotic concentrations is placed on a culture plate inoculated with the bacterium.

Process

The strip releases the antibiotic, creating a gradient in the medium. An elliptical zone of inhibition forms around the strip after incubation.

Determination

The MIC is identified at the point where the edge of the ellipse intersects with the strip, representing the lowest concentration of the antibiotic that inhibits bacterial growth (MIC). (Option C)

Advantages

Allows for the simultaneous testing of multiple antibiotics on a single plate and provides a visual, precise measurement of the MIC, enhancing accuracy compared to traditional disk diffusion methods.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a history of recurrent episodes of jaundice, fatigue, and abdominal pain. Physical examination reveals splenomegaly. options.label: C
options.text: In HS patients, high osmotic fragility leads to a right shift on the graph.

options.text: Normally, RBC lysis begins at 0.7% NaCl.

Detachment occurs as uterine contractions increase

Marginal areas are unsupported, leading to separation

questions.text: A 15-year-old male is undergoing puberty and starts experiencing physical and hormonal changes associated with this developmental stage. Which hormonal changes and effects are typical during puberty in males?

options.label: C
options.text: Elevated FSH enlarges penis and scrotum.

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased LH boosts testosterone production.
questions.explanation:
Puberty and Male Reproductive System Changes

Increased Testosterone Production
  • Surge in testosterone by Leydig cells in testes. Stimulated by LH from anterior pituitary. (Option B)

Primary Sexual Characteristics
  • Growth of penis, scrotum, and testes. (Option C)

Secondary Sexual Characteristics
  • Body Hair: Increased growth on pubic area, face, chest, etc.
  • Voice Changes: Deeper voice due to larynx hypertrophy.
  • Skin Changes: Thicker skin, increased sebaceous secretion, acne.
  • Muscle Development: Increased muscle mass (50% greater than females). (Option A)
  • Bone Growth: Enhanced thickness, calcium retention.
  • Metabolic Effects: Increased basal metabolic rate (5-10%), potential increase in red blood cells.

Spermatogenesis
  • Sperm production begins and continues throughout life within seminiferous tubules of testes.

Role of Hormones in Spermatogenesis
  • FSH: Stimulates Sertoli cells for sperm support.
  • Testosterone: Essential for germ cell growth.
  • Inhibin: Produced by Sertoli cells to regulate FSH and spermatogenesis rate. (Option D)

Sperm Maturation and Storage
  • Immature sperm mature in the epididymis, gaining motility (suppressed until ejaculation), stored for at least a month.

Peristalsis

Contraction Amplitude

10-45 mmHg

Complete relaxation occur i.e ≤8 mmHg)

Coordinated peristalsis throughout

Normal amplitude is <180 mmHg

Elevated (>45 mmHg)

Incomplete relaxation (>8 mmHg)

Absent in the esophageal body

N/A

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with swelling in her right calf and foot, which has gradually worsened over the past few years. She reports that the swelling started in her teenage years and has become more pronounced with time. What is the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Congenital Lymphedema (Option A)

Lymphedema Tarda (Option C)
  • Age: Seen in < 1 year of age
  • Present at birth.
  • Lower limb, genitalia, and face are involved.
  • Usually B/L and multiple limbs are involved.
  • Familial version of congenital lymphedema – known as Milroy’s disease.
  • M/C type of primary lymphedema (>90% of cases).
  • Age: 1 to 35 years.
  • M/C seen in females.
  • Usually U/L.
  • Involves calf and foot
  • Familial version of lymphedema praecox - known as Meig's disease.
  • Age: Usually seen in > 35 years age group

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a persistent dry cough and shortness of breath. A CT scan of the chest reveals localized airway obstruction at the level of the terminal bronchioles. Based on Weibel's classification of the respiratory system, which generation of airways is most likely affected in this patient?

A child presented with a sore throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes in the neck. Throat culture was subjected to Albert's stain and revealed bacilli arranged in a Chinese letter pattern. The patient's condition deteriorates rapidly, with signs of severe respiratory distress. Which of the following mechanisms is primarily responsible for the clinical manifestations seen in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Cleavage of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide by Diphtheria Toxin (DT).

options.label: B
options.text: Inactivation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2) by Exotoxin A.

options.label: C
options.text: Binding of fragment B to human cell receptors by Diphtheria Toxin (DT).

options.label: D
options.text: Secretion of toxins by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.correct_answer: C. Binding of fragment B to human cell receptors by Diphtheria Toxin (DT).
questions.explanation:
Toxin

Source

Mechanism of Action

Diphtheria Toxin (DT)

Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • Secreted by bacteria infected with tox-carrying β-phage.
  • Cleaved into fragments B and A.
  • Fragment B binds to human cell receptors.
  • Fragment A ADP-ribosylates elongation factor 2 (EF-2), halting protein synthesis.

Exotoxin A

Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • Secreted by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • Inhibits protein synthesis in eukaryotic cells.
  • The mechanism involves a similar process to DT, disrupting EF-2 function.

The mechanism by which the eyes focus diverging rays from a near object on the retina

Ciliary muscles contract →Zonules relax→Lens becomes more convex anteriorly

Presbyopia

Physiological insufficiency of accommodation, causing worsening near vision after the age of 40

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to a throbbing headache. On vital examination, BP is 210/140 mm Hg. She is started on a Nitroprusside IV drip. After 8 hours, develop lactic acidosis and neurological symptoms. She is diagnosed with nitroprusside-induced cyanide toxicity. Which of the following drug combinations is used to treat this condition?
questions.correct_answer: B. Sodium nitrite + sodium thiosulfate + hydroxocobalamin
questions.explanation:
Option A: Pralidoxime + atropine

  • This combination of drugs serves as an antidote for organophosphate poisoning.
  • Atropine is used for atropinization of all the nicotinic and muscarinic receptors thus preventing their further stimulation, while pralidoxime is used to reverse the inhibited acetylcholinesterase and reactivate the enzyme .

Option C: Activated charcoal + N-acetyl cysteine

  • This combination of drugs is used to treat acetaminophen/paracetamol poisoning.
  • Activated charcoal binds to the unabsorbed paracetamol present in the gut which can be flushed out using a lavage, while N-acetyl cysteine serves to replenish the glutathione stores which binds to the toxic metabolite of paracetamol N-acetyl-p-benzoquinoneimine.

Option D: Sodium nitrite only

  • If only sodium nitrite is used, the cyanmethemoglobin formed will dissociate back into cyanide and methemoglobin before being excreted out of the body.

Cyanide poisoning

Sodium nitrite + sodium thiosulfate + hydroxocobalamin.

Organophosphate poisoning

Pralidoxime + atropine.

Paracetamol poisoning

Activated charcoal + N-acetyl cysteine.

questions.text: A patient on long-term lithium therapy visits with complaints of frequent urination and increased thirst. He was diagnosed with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI) based on urine analysis and plasma ADH levels. He was prescribed a combination of amiloride and hydrochlorothiazide. What is the reason for the use of thiazide diuretics in nephrogenic DI?

options.label: A
options.text: Thiazides reduce urine output by increasing free water absorption in proximal tubules

options.label: B
options.text: Thiazides directly increase the sensitivity of the kidneys to ADH.

options.label: C
options.text: Thiazides help to increase lithium excretion, reducing its nephrotoxic effects.

options.label: D
options.text: Thiazides decrease the risk of hypokalemia when used with amiloride.

questions.correct_answer: A. Thiazides reduce urine output by increasing free water absorption in proximal tubules
questions.explanation:
Drug

Mechanism

Thiazide diuretics

Induce mild volume depletion → ↑ proximal tubular reabsorption of water → ↓ urine output

Amiloride

Blocks ENaC channels in collecting ducts → ↓ lithium uptake → renal protection

Lithium

Causes nephrogenic DI by damaging ADH-sensitive pathways in collecting ducts

Duration

At least 6 months

Reduces conductive and sensorineural hearing loss

Stabilizes hearing loss, reduces dizziness and tinnitus.

At least 6 months

Stabilizes hearing loss

Relieves vestibular symptoms

Ribozyme

Protein enzymes

Key similarities

Both act as catalysts

Both exhibit specificity, meaning they act on specific molecules (substrates) and catalyse specific reactions. (Option B ruled out)

Both types of enzymes work by lowering the activation energy of reactions

Key differences

Made up of amino acids

Greater structural complexity
